data.title: Much Ado about Nought - Oro Pesi Je!
data.text:
Otunba Oyenuga,

You have not explained the presence of Mr Abraham Adesanya in the entourage. Despite all the hot air about progressivusm, Hausa-Fulani this and that, the fact remains that the Yoruba remain the staunchest allies of the Hausa-Fulani in the Nigerian power game. Likewise, all the noise about southern governors and southern solidarity is mere hot air. The position taken by the obasanjo and Bola Ige duo in relation to resource control is far more reflective of the true position of the SW- Northern alliance which has been in power since 1967. All the noisy stuff simply masks the identity of interest between the Yoruba and the Hausa Fulani and their strategic aim of maintaining the Nigerian status quo. The outcome of the Chikago protests is the greatest validation yet of our concept of dual morality which will soon receive a rigorous treatment in a future edition of The Journal of Igbo Affairs.

I feel sorry for those Igbo chaps who are pushed into the forefront of phoney activism and abandoned midway. Every generation of Ndiigbo experiences this phenomenon but nobody learns. Yesterday Ezeife, today the addle-headed Chicago protesters. Tufia!

Why was Adesanya there? Oro Pesi Je!

Mz Ani

>Date: Tue, 27 Feb 2001 09:06:43 -0800

>From: Adey Oyenuga <oye...@chapman.edu>

>To: Hamza Brimah <mza...@pol.net>

>Subject: Re: Much ado about Nought - Oh Really?

>Reply-To: oye...@chapman.edu

>

>Hello Honorable Doc,

>

>In part, you wrote: "I am mature enough to set aside my personal

>disdain for military leaders, especially the cruel and evil examples

>such as Babangida, and recognize that Gen. Abdulsalam truly

>deserves credit for sticking to his promise and relinquishing his

>accidentally occurring leadership position, in record time, much

>to the surprise of many distrustful Nigerians".

>

>Splendid.....

>

>By the way, I doubt if most of the "protesters" were really against

>Gen. Abdulsalami Abubakar. Personally speaking, I believe that

>their main beef was mostly directed at IBB (and maybe Buhari).

>Hence, once they (i.e. the protesters) learned that IBB (or Buhari)

>won't be at the infamous (or ceremonius) lecture series, most of

>them simply stayed away. Please see below:

>

>"IBBs expected presence had fuelled great excitement among

>Nigerians who have expressed displeasure with the Chicago State

>University....

>

>In response to a letter of protest by a former Nigerian Student

>Union activist who is now in the US, Mr. Sowore Omoyele, the

>president of the Chicago State University said the university had

>not invited IBB nor is the former military dictator on the list of

>participants expected at the lecture.

>

>According to the letter: 'I am writing in response to your inquiry

>regarding the honouring of General Ibrahim Badamosi Babangida.

>Please rest assured that this individual has not been invited to

>attend our lectureship and is not on our list of participants.

>

>Moreover, while I applaud your concern about the atrocities

>committed by various individuals in Nigeria, we are a university

>located in a democracy, and as such, committed to fostering

>dialogue around issues of international concern. Indeed, the

>knowledge development process necessarily requires an exchange

>of convergent and divergent ideas and opinions, which then

>engender a discourse that represents the totality of ideas.'"

>

>Now, the question that begs to be asked is quite a simple one;

>How would you feel if Chicago State University were to have

>a so-called lecture series in honor of IBB? That is, would you

>also be "mature enough to set aside your personal disdain for

>military leaders, and recognize" that of IBB"?

>

>Personally, though I was reluctant to participate in the "noise

>making" exercise, I can't help but to commend some of those

>who took the initiative to voice their respective opinions either

>vehemently or otherwise. You see, as Dr. Elnora Daniel was

>quick to point out, "......the knowledge development process

>necessarily requires an exchange of convergent and divergent

>ideas and opinions, which then engender a discourse that

>represents the totality of ideas.....".

>

>As a matter of fact, I believe that, Chicago State University or

>other institutions are now going to think twice before inviting or

>celebrating any family-member of the notorious Nigeria's Juntas.

>Trust me.... The line has been drawn. Thus, props to all parties

>in this affair.

>

>

>Adey Oyenuga.

>

>

>

>Hamza Brimah wrote:

>

>> Elnora Daniel,

>> c/o Larry Robinson,

>> Chicago State University.

>>

>> Dear Ma'am,

>>

>> I would like to apologize for the tasteless attacks you have received

>> from some of my fellowcountrymen, whose energies could be better

>> spent focusing on the real issues affecting Nigerians and Africans.

>> I do not defend 'military' leadership, but I do see the sense in

>> recognizing a rare Ruler, such as Gen Abdulsalam, who actually

>> relinquished leadership, and quickly too, to a democratically elected

>> ruler.

>> A quick check of Africa's past 50 years, reveals that less than 1%

>> of our leaders, be they military or civilian, have ever peacefully

>> relinquished leadership at any level, neither from Egypt to Congo,

>> nor from Kenya to Liberia.

>> I am mature enough to set aside my personal disdain for military

>> leaders, especially the cruel and evil examples such as Babangida,

>> and recognize that Gen. Abdulsalam truly deserves credit for sticking

>> to his promise and relinquishing his accidentally occurring

>> leadership position, in record time, much to the surprise of many

>> distrustful Nigerians. He also returned the "freedom of speech" to a

>> nation scared to whisper in the bathroom under the Dictator Abacha.

>> Finally, may I close, by pointing out a few other rare African

>> leaders, Mandela for all the obvious reasons, Gaddafi for his keen

>> vision of the importance of African UNITY, and Rawlings for raising

>> the living standards of his people, because rare is the African

>> leader who leaves his people BETTER OFF, than he met them.

>> May the example of this Abdulsalam Award encourage other African

>> despots to give up and get out too. I expect that there are those who

>> would vehemently oppose my position here, but I hope they may

>> appreciate the points I have raised.

>> This concludes my personal opinion on this matter.

>> Respectfully yours,

>> Humbly Hamza

>> The African Slave

Chief Adepoju,

Otunba Adey Ayenuga has not come to terms with what Mr Adesanya

has done. A couple of weeks ago, he was waxing lyrical about Alhaji Shagari

commissioning a project in Abia State. He wheeled

out his decrepit snake oil theory to caution Ndiigbo about the dangers of

dealing with the North.

Now his hero, the future Aare Ona Kakanfo himself is tagging along in the

role of a 3rd fiddler to an ex-military dictator, the arch-ogre and the

Hausa-Fulani hegemonist personified- Mr Abdusalam Abubakar. otunpa Ayenuga

is singing a different tone. Otunba Ayenuga has demonstrated the whole

spectrum of what can go wrong with the politics of moral duality. Those Igbo

who allowed themselves to be so cynically manipulated over the Chicago will

be gnashing their teeth just like Ezeife, Udenta etc before them

This event has damaged all of Adesanya's claims to credibility and confirmed

the janus-faced manipulation that has been conceptualised as dual morality.

It is this sort of action that will make it impossible for Nigeria too be a

single state for long. Now Otunba Oyenuga is beating his chest about Yoruba

power while believing that political party registration should be an act of

charity dished out by Hausa-Fulani military fiat to which Adesanya will be

eternally grateful. What a farce.

And so, within a short space of two weeks, Otunba Oyenuga has moved from

southern solidarity through cautioning the Igbo about dealing with the North

to a warm emrace with the North in the name of politics which he now

conceptualises as a dirty game! From advising the Igbo against alliance with

the North, Otunba Oyenuga the janus-faced strategist now cautions Ndiigbo

against being hollier than thou! What a load of crap! What a load of

nonsense!

Azi gba!

Mz Ani

>being played....Live by the sword, die by the sword. I hope

>man sang like a canary. Yeye man!

>To understand how the Military operated during Abacha's era,

>Malu pointed out..... It was really a jungle-military. Kill

>or be killed.

>

>Like I stated, these Military Juntas have their own ways of

>dealing with national/political matters. In a few cases, it

>close insiders, some were put through ill-tests. A few were

>that Gen. Abubakar went after Abacha's loots...and, he also

>painted Abacha's family in a negative light, before passing

>the torch to Uncle Sege. Chei, and some of us are wondering

>why Uncle Sege isn't going after IBB yet? Nothing but Smoke.

>

>Uncle Sege is well schooled in these military games. Indeed,

>he is no spring chicken....He knows when to play along. And

>he knows when to fold his cards. The king-makers can always

>crown a new king. He has managed to escape all traps set in

>his ways....

>

>Is Gen. Abubakar a Saint? Is the Pope a Muslim? Heck no! Is

>Uncle Sege a Saint? Is Santa Claus real? Heck no!

>

>Should Gen. Abubakar be spending his "ill-gotten monies" in

>the US, instead of in Nigeria? A no-brainer, however, it is

>a good example of why Nigeria is the way she is today. This

>goes to show that our so-called leaders are very "misplaced

>elites".

>

>But I assume your main beef is towards Pa Adesanya. If need

>be, he may have no choice but to address this burning issue

>in the future. However - until then - I reiterate that I am

>willing to give him the benefit of the doubt...Rest assured,

>I respect your rights or that of others to express negative

>views against his "jollification" with Gen. Abubakar. But I

>believe that there is more to this that meet our collective

>eyes.

>

>Again, I'm sorry to learn about your mom's passing. May her

>soul rest in a perfect peace.

>

>

>Adey Oyenuga.

>

>p.s.: As I bang on these keys, I'm listening to Pa Ogunde's

>lyrics on "Yoruba R'onu". What an epic and informed recital.
